description.narrative:
FAO har ansökt finansiering av 49 miljoner kronor för att genomföra projektet " Strengthening the implementation of land restitution policy - Phase II " i Colombia under perioden 1 december 2016 till 30 nov 2019.
Insatsen syftar till att förbättra förutsättningarna för en hållbar utveckling för män och kvinnor på landsbygden som drabbats av konflikten genom samordning av offentliga och privata aktörer. För åstadkomma detta är de tre förväntade resultaten: 1) Att etniska grupper som fördrivits från och tvingats överge land i områden som prioriteras av Enheten för markrestitution (URT) har tillgång till markrestitutionsprocessen. 2) Att familjer som fått tillbaka sin mark i prioriterade landsbygdsområden som har drabbats av väpnade konflikter förbättrar sin hållbara försörjning (i sociala, miljömässiga och ekonomiska aspekter) 3) Att URT samt offentliga och privata enheter stärker sina processer och samordning för att erbjuda en integrerad lösning till landsbygdsbefolkningen.
Insatsens totala budget är 49 miljoner kronor och är 100% finansierad av Sverige.

FAO has applied to Sida for funding of 49 million SEK to carry out the project “Strengthening the implementation of land restitution policy -Phase II” in Colombia during the period December 1, 2016 to November 30 2019.
The intervention aims at improving conditions for sustainable development for men and women in rural areas affected by the conflict through the articulation of different public and private actors. To do so, the three expected outcomes are 1) Ethnic Communities victims of dispossession or forced abandon, in areas prioritized by the Land Restitution Unit (URT), have access to the land restitution process; 2) Families of settled peasant communities in prioritized areas affected by armed conflict, improve their sustainable livelihoods (social, environmental and economic conditions); and 3) Land Restitution Unit (URT) and public and private entities strengthen their intervention and coordination to offer an integral response to the rural population and its territories.
The intervention’s total budget is 49 million SEK and is 100% financed by Sweden.

The intervention aims at improving conditions for sustainable development for men and women in rural areas affected by the conflict through the articulation of different public and private actors. To do so, the three expected outcomes are 1) Ethnic Communities victims of dispossession or forced abandon, in areas prioritized by the Land Restitution Unit (URT), have access to the land restitution process; 2) Families of settled peasant communities in prioritized areas affected by armed conflict, improve their sustainable livelihoods (social, environmental and economic conditions); and 3) Land Restitution Unit (URT) and public and private entities strengthen their intervention and coordination to offer an integral response to the rural population and its territories.

tag.narrative: 1.2 - By 2030, reduce at least by half the proportion of men, women and children of all ages living in poverty in all its dimensions according to national definitions.
1.2 - Till 2030 minst halvera den andel män, kvinnor och barn i alla åldrar som lever i någon form av fattigdom enligt nationella definitioner.
16.1 - Avsevärt minska alla former av våld och dödligt våld överallt.
16.1 - Significantly reduce all forms of violence and related death rates everywhere.

2.3 - By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous peoples, family farmers, pastoralists and fishers, including through secure and equal access to land, other productive resources and inputs, knowledge, financial services, markets and opportunities for value addition and non-farm employment.

2.3 - Till 2030 fördubbla jordbrukets produktivitet och inkomster för småskaliga livsmedelsproducenter, i synnerhet kvinnor, ursprungsfolk, familjejordbrukare, boskapsskötande nomader samt fiskare, inklusive genom säker och lika tillgång till mark, andra produktionsresurser och insatsvaror, kunskap, finansiella tjänster och marknader samt möjligheter till värdeskapande och sysselsättning utanför jordbruket.
5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.

8.3 - Främja utvecklingsinriktad politik som stöder produktiv verksamhet, skapande av anständiga arbetstillfällen, företagande, kreativitet och innovation samt uppmuntra att mikroföretag liksom små och medelstora företag växer och blir en del av den formella ekonomin, bland annat genom tillgång till finansiella tjänster.

8.3 - Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.

description.narrative: As mentioned by the evaluation and in the statement of narrative report, this project has been very relevant and effective. Seven planned collective restitution processes were registered in the seized lands registry, achieving the goal of having 9 characterization processes finished: five including 21 indigenous peoples in 7 Departments and four including afro Colombians in 4 Departments. The nine processes are claiming the restitution of 755,810ha of lands for 12,542 people. The characterization process has also contributed to: raising awareness about the impact of conflict in these communities; recovering their traditions; strengthening their administrative and productive capacities; as well as resolving some interethnic conflicts. The second result was implemented through the strategy for local networks of productive integration (RLIP is its Spanish acronym), that was consolidated during the last two years for improving socio economic and environmental sustainability of local businesses. The RLIP strategy has a territorial approach that aims at changing specific regional challenges and opportunities, integrating families that were displaced and restituted and other families that resisted during the conflict or were opponents to the restitution process and remained in the territory, as well as public and private stakeholders. The productive associations were the integrating mechanism for promoting solidarity among the community and for resolving conflicts. In each region, the Project has identified a baseline of the strongest business model and has developed a tailor-made action plan to improve productivity of crops, honey or dairy production, but also technical support for improving their associations in financial, accounting systems, sales and marketing, among other issues. 28 organizations were strengthened, within the framework of 13 productive ventures. These organizations include 1,755 people (675 women and 1080 men) that have received accompaniment. In each region, the families were organized into small hubs to promote teamwork, strengthen the social fabric of the closest neighbors and jointly monitor progress in environmental, economic, social and coordination indicators. With this strategy, a total investment of $660,600 USD was made in 11 associations that boosted sales of $1,474,000USD and $262,000 USD in the rotary funds of 9 regions. The productivity rate has risen by an average 264%, compared to the baseline in 2019 and the incomes per family have increased by 28% during the whole period. In addition to the main business models, each community also developed social projects to promote reconciliation, historical memory and in some cases, women’s economic empowerment. The RLIP strategy included a strong gender focus where 1,321 participants (45% women) received training in topics including: transforming traditional gender roles; new masculinities and care economy; leadership; teamwork; conflict resolution; political participation; and nondiscrimination. As a result, women’s participation in decision making structures, such as association directive boards, has increased from 31% to 41%. Women’s participation in rotary funds has also increased from 0 to 35%. 40% of participants in more than 70 meetings and discussions with local authorities or chambers of commerce to influence reparation plans or commercial agreements, were also women leaders. As regards the environmental tools, the communities of those regions participated in specific training for soil and water management, integrated pest management, good farming and milking practices, flora and fauna conservation. 62% of participants have appropriated environmental tools for agricultural production. As regards the third output, the inter institutional coordination plans are developed annually by all the relevant institutions in the prioritized regions. During 2018, 9 inter institutional coordination plans (PAIT is Spanish acronym) were approved and 6 were approved in 2019, with the participation of 194 institutions at a national and local level, identifying actual bottlenecks for rulings' compliance and victims' needs for integral reparation. These PAIT identified 71 priorities of which 73% have been implemented. For instance, tertiary roads’ maintenance, property titles of lands, housing, public services such as water or electricity. However, as stated by the evaluators, there are still many challenges to integrate the territorial perspective and strengthen coordination among public institutions.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
